I would hypothesize that the drop is being propelled by the Magnus-effect.  The initial imbalance causes a motion in one specific direction ( over the alternative vector ), and the evaporating liquid nitrogen vapor moving differentially quickly over the 'front' side of the droplet ( the side facing its forward motion vector ) produces lift in that direction.   I'm hypothesizing that its 'forward' motion is due to the Magnus effect instead of the Bernoulli effect because I would expect the oil droplet to have some form of angular momentum upon forming, and this angular momentum likely causes the droplet's initial direction of travel, and initializes the Magnus effect due to its initial spin.   All just a guess, but one I'd bet some cookies on....

An interesting version of this same effect is when casting certain metals into sub boiling water. In the video linked the molten copper alloy is poured onto a suspended canvas cloth that is submerged in sub boiling water. The jacket of steam prevents the liquid metal from burning through the cloth "mould" and also produces a very clean ingot. As the metal cools and the steam jacket dissipates, you can actually hear the water briefly come back to a boil as it finally contacts the hot metal surface. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NDzBswHxr7s

Which oil exactly did you use? Is it by chance less dense than the nitrogen?
LN2 is around 0.8g/ml, silicone oils are between 0.7 to 0.9. Similar density + surface tension (though LN2 has a low one) might be the main cause it stays up even after its frozen and has the same temperature as the nitrogen, rather than just the trapped nitrogen bubble underneath (which would have no real reason to evaporate at a considerable rate if the drop is just as cold as the nitrogen). It can be tested at even lower ambient temperatures, so that the nitrogen doesnt evaporate at a considerable rate. If the drop still floats after reaching the same temperature as the nitrogen then it has very little, or close nothing at all, to do with Leidenfrost. Might as well be floating the oil on water.

Is it inverse though? I don't think the definition of Leidenfrost effect explicitly states which part should be producing the vapour. It's only us giving the example of a water droplet on a stove that has us thinking that there has to be a droplet at all. To quote Wikipedia (yeah, I know it's not the best source but still) "The Leidenfrost effect is a physical phenomenon in which a liquid, in near contact with a mass significantly hotter than the liquid's boiling point, produces an insulating vapor layer keeping that liquid from boiling rapidly." For example when a hot steel ball is dropped into water, it is Leidenfrost effect that keeps it from rapidly cooling and boiling the water.
